newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul stocks close lower in consolidation.
newsitem.headline: Seoul stocks close lower in consolidation.

text.p: Stocks closed lower on Tuesday in what brokers said is a consolidation following the last week's rises.
Brokers said the high level of margin loans at brokerage houses was also a factor affecting the general sentiment.
The composite index provisionally ended at 819.22, down 1.61 percent or 13.40 points.
"Selling was broad-based, even though trading volume was very low," said Noh Byoung-keuk of Coryo Securities.
Volume totalled 26.05 million shares, down from 34.72 million on Monday.
Margin loans which investors owed to brokerage firms stood at around 2.9 trillion won as of Monday, outpacing customer deposits estimated at around 2.8 trillion, brokers said.

"Recently investors increased buying on margin loans in anticipation of rising customer deposits. But deposit growth was much slower than they expected and investors are now selling to repay loans," said Yoo Jae-kyong of Daishin Securities.
Declining stocks beat advancers by 782 to 163.
Brokers said an unexpected sharp rise in bond yields also took its toll on the overall sentiment.

Bond market dealers said yields on the benchmark three-year corporate bonds rose 16 basis points to 12.10 percent on Tuesday on market talk that next month's supply would be more than previously expected.
Brokers said hopes for a steady decline in the interest rates had been behind the recent strength of the stock market.
The index futures December contracts ended 1.1 points lower at 86.10 and the KOSPI-200 index fell 1.34 points to 85.96.
